ao_description: An extraordinary "City of Caves" carved from solid stone.
A centuries-old lookout post still sits atop a natural stone spire.
Nineteen ancient rock-cut Buddhist caves can be found on the outskirts of Mumbai.
World's most expensive home.
A Zoroastrian funerary tower where excarnation rituals are carried out is threatened by the area's dwindling vulture population.
A 66-million-year-old rock formation stands tall over Mumbai, offering stellar city views.
In Mumbai, a bright blue synagogue is the largest one for the Baghdadi Jewish community in Asia.
Tucked in Mumbai’s wealthiest neighborhood is one of the city’s oldest and most sacred sites: a temple complex believed to house the waters of the Ganges.
The only Chinese temple in Mumbai.
The place of worship for Zoroastrians, Mumbai's Parsi fire temples use fire and ash for purification.
A 19th-century church in South Mumbai built to commemorate those who died in the First Anglo-Afghan War and the retreat from Kabul in 1842.
These animal carvings stand as a representation of India and Britain.
Mumbai's angel.
An architectural marvel that combines Gothic architecture with Indian elements.
Constructed in 1923, this is one of several heritage drinking fountains across Mumbai.
An 18th-century fort in the business district of Mumbai.
A drinking water fountain in the heart of Mumbai, built by a father in memory of his son.
A heritage structure designed in 1882 honors a Parsi philanthropist.
A tribute to one of Bombay's former governors that has withstood the test of time.
Located in the Horniman Circle area, this church marks the historical Zero Point of Mumbai.
Designed as a 17th-century watchtower, the former fort is now a popular sunset haunt.
A sandstone lamp post in Mumbai's business district honors the war efforts of the Port Trust and its employees who fell during World War I.
This 19th-century heritage building once housed a department store that supplied British provisions in the city.
A gigantic shoe, inspired by a nursery rhyme, sits in a park atop Mumbai’s Malabar Hill.
A tribute to the area's namesake and King Edward VII.
